awd_titl_txt: NeTS:  Small:  Collaborative Research:  Cooperative Interference-Embracing Communication in Multi-Hop Wireless Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
While the proliferation of wireless devices and their Internet-centered applications has brought forth numerous wireless services, current wireless technologies are unable to meet the increasing communication demand caused by the huge number of wireless devices and the scarcity of available radio spectrum. The proposed research will make a concrete step toward bridging this gap by developing new communication algorithms and protocols for wireless networks, specifically multi-hop wireless networks. Multi-hop communication brings many benefits such as enlarged network coverage, reduced radio transmit power, and relaxed requirements for network infrastructure, yet interference severely degrades network performance. This project investigates this fundamental issue by developing practical approaches to managing interference in multi-hop wireless networks, with the objective of maximizing their throughput performance. The success of this project will advance the field's knowledge of wireless system design and implementation, significantly improve network throughput performance, and enlarge the network communication coverage, yielding ubiquitous high data rate wireless services. The project will also provide opportunities for research training for underrepresented students at undergraduate and graduate levels, and project results will be widely disseminated through high-profile tutorials, talks, publications, software toolkits, and open-source sites. 

The goal of this project is to develop novel, practical, and foundational interference-embracing solutions to improve the throughput of multi-hop wireless networks by leveraging recent advances in physical layer techniques, and to evaluate such solutions using real-world implementations. Focusing on theory, protocol design, and system prototyping for interference management technologies, this project presents a comprehensive solution for advanced interference management in multi-hop wireless networks, including interference cancellation, interference alignment, and interference neutralization. In addition to significantly advancing interference management techniques for multi-hop wireless communications, this project will provide training opportunities for students spanning signal processing, optimization, algorithmic development, and networking infrastructure research; support talented female and underrepresented Ph.D. students in the completion of their doctoral studies; result in the dissemination of research results through high-profile tutorials, talks, publications, software toolkits, and open-source sites; and integrate research results into the development of new courses at both the University of Louisville and the University of Nebraska-Lincoln.

por.por_cntn:
The ever-growing number of wireless devices and the shortage of available sub-6GHz spectrum have led to new types of wireless systems incorporating multi-hop communication techniques. Compared to single-hop communication, multi-hop communication brings many advantages such as enlarged network coverage, reduced radio transmit power, and relaxed requirement of network infrastructure. As such, multi-hop communication has been incorporated into real-world wireless systems such as LTE Relay and IEEE 802.11s. In multi-hop wireless networks, interference is a fundamental problem causing severe performance degradation. While many interference management techniques have been proposed in the literature, most of them are limited to single-hop networks. The advancement of interference management techniques for multi-hop networks remains very limited.

This project focuses on developing practical yet efficient interference-embracing techniques to improve the throughput of multi-hop wireless networks by leveraging recent advances in physical-layer signal processing, and evaluating the proposed techniques through real-world implementation and experimentation. Specifically, three interference-embracing techniques have been studied and evaluated in this project: spatial-domain interference alignment and cancellation (SD-IAC), frequency-domain interference alignment and cancellation (FD-IAC), and interference neutralization and cancellation (INC).

The performance limits of SD-IAC were studied for multi-hop wireless networks where each node has multiple antennas. A cross-layer optimization framework has been proposed to maximize the end-to-end throughput of multiple communication sessions in the presence of mutual interference. Efficient algorithms have been developed to solve the formulated optimization problems, yielding near-optimal solutions for user scheduling, resource allocation, and interference management. Analytical and numerical results show that the proposed SD-IAC algorithms can significantly improve network throughput compared to conventional interference avoidance approaches. In addition to theoretical exploration, practical challenges in the implementation of SD-IAC have been investigated. For example, the implementation of SD-IAC is reliant on transmitter-side channel state information (CSI); yet the channel feedback tends to entail a large amount of airtime overhead and therefore compromise the gain of SD-IAC. To address this challenge, a deep-learning-based (autoencoder) scheme was proposed for CSI compression. Experimental results show that the proposed scheme can reduce the airtime overhead of channel feedback by more than 70% in Wi-Fi networks while maintaining the same CSI feedback accuracy.

In addition, the performance bounds of FD-IAC and INC have investigated for wireless cognitive radio networks that comprise primary users (incumbent users) and secondary users (cognitive users). While most existing works in the literature consider the case where primary and secondary users cooperate with each other to manage interference for spectrum sharing, this project focuses on a more realistic but challenging case where secondary users take the full responsibility for mitigating the interference from/to co-located primary users. To address this challenge, an interference cancellation scheme that does not require CSI was proposed for secondary receivers to decode their data packet in the presence of interference from primary users; and an implicit beamforming scheme was proposed to pre-cancel the interference for primary receivers by taking advantage of channel reciprocity. The proposed FD-IAC and INC schemes were implemented on software-defined radio (SDR) testbeds. Experimental results show that the secondary users can successfully mitigate interference from/to primary users while requiring neither cooperation nor knowledge about primary transmissions.

This project has supported three graduate students and five undergraduate students. The blend of theoretical research and experimental development offers students unique experience with modern wireless communication systems, helping them become future experts and leaders of wireless industry. This project has produced 9 journal publications and 11 conference papers/presentations. Particularly, one of the conference papers received the Best Paper Award from IEEE International Conference on Sensing, Communication and Networking (SECON), 2021.
